div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: Ill-Placed Sympathy
div.p: A Zulu living in Edinburgh has been delighted by a letter from Mr. Keir Hardie. In that etter Mr. Hardie expresses a tender sympathy with the native rebels with whom his country men are engaged in a small but necessary war. He express a hope that the day will speedily come when the Zulus will be able to defend themselves against the barbarities perpetrated on them by hypocritical whites, who regard the black man as having been created in order that they might exploit him for their own advantage." Incidentally he

div.head: Ill placed sympathy continued
div.p: remarks : ‘ The terrible event which happened in the Soudan (sic) the other day, with its attendant brutalities, reduces the administration of that country under British rule to the level of that of the Congo Free State, while the wholesale massacre of natives which is now going on in South Africa, under the pretext of suppressing a rebellion which does not exist, fills one with shame and horror.”

The Zulu living in Edinburgh, who probably believes in his own nation and retains some sentiment of patriotism, mast have been astonished to read each sentences, says the "Evening Standard and St. James’s Gazette.” He does not know that Mr. Keir Hardie belongs to a clique which invariably ranges itself on the side of the enemies of England, and does all it can to harm the country to which it owes its birth and its bread. We who do know Mr. Keir Hardie and his friends have reached a stage at which we cannot be surprised by their sayings and doings. It is imcpossible to argue with them, or we might point oat a few facts which prevent the administration of England in Egypt being compared with that of King Leopold on the Congo, and might also question Mr. Hardie s implication that the rebellion in South Africa has been only supposed to exist in order that British soldiers may enjoy the slaughter of Zulus. No, we cannot argue with them The utmost we can attempt is the suggestion to Hr. Keir Hardie of a course of action which, with his high-flown humanitarianism, he should be eager to accept It is simplicity itself. There is a Zulu in Edinburgh educating himself, we believe, in accordance with Scottish ideals. Why should not there be a Scotsman in South Africa educating himself in Colonial necessities ?

What we propose is that Mr. Keir Har'ie should emigrate to South Africa and settle, if only for a time, within the circle of our present military operations. To make the scheme complete it will be necessary for Mr. Hardie to tike his wife and children with him. Otherwise he would not be able to enter into the feelings of the South African colonist.

Imagine Mr. Hardie, blessed by the Pro- Zulus of well-guarded London, far from his comfortable home and the sturdy sons of Labour who retain their faith in his statesmanlike qualities, domiciled on the veldt He goes out in the morning to earn a living by the sweat of his brow, not by declamations against capital and military force. As he set forth knowing that the natives have a knack of descending like wolves on the fold, he discovers that firearms have their uses. He thinks with regret of the policemen in Palace-yard and of the two stalwart Life Guards doing nothing in Whitehall; he wonders whether his home will be as he left it when he returns. His home is liable to be burnt; his children to be slain; his wife to be subjected to outrage. There is no help far or near. The authorities, let us suppose, have taken his advice. They have refrained from killing natives. No more money is being spent on punitive forces. Each Colonist is left to defend himself and his beloved possessions. We should like to hear Mr.Hardie’s observations in such circumstances. Would his humanitarianism uphold him ? Would he remain a lover of his brother Zulu ? Would he continue to believe that the black peril is a myth of the Colonist’s fancy?

It is so easy, so pitifully easy, for Mr. Keir Hardie and all Pro-Boers and Pro-Zulus and Pro-any-enemies-of-their country to write fiery letters and deliver fiery speeches, and then go to bed in the blissful knowledge that if some naughty little boy raps their door without cause they will be able to fetch a policeman from round the corner. They are the first people to howl if they are struck, bat so long as their own skins are safe there is no ending to their denomination of the brother Englishman who hits out in self-defense. Illogical, crazy, selfish, small-minded, distorted creatures they are properly considered, the real dregs of the people. If one and all they took op their camps and deposited themselves in some desert place—South Africa or elsewhere—their country would be the purer and better for the riddance, while the spot whereon they settled would soon be no worse : the native inhabitants would see to that.

Our indignation is not roused by the few who, honestly believing that such-and-such a war or campaign is unjust, fight against it while it is bat imminent, and when it is certain drop their voices and say no more. Unjust wire there have been—unjust wars there will be so long as fallible man remains on the earth. Let ns try to prevent them to the utmost of our power. Bat, when once they have been undertaken, let us, in the name of humanity as well as national pride and virtue, abstain from encouraging the foe.

In this case there is no injustice. If Mr. Keir Hardie sees injustice where none exists, that is the fan It of his intelligence rather than of his heart. But his abuse of England, his encouragement and glorification of criminal Egyptians and Zulus a thirst for blood, are aberrations of character which cat him off from the society of all patriotic, of all right minded Englishmen.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Plague.No farther cases of bobonic plague are reported in any part of the country. A patient at Samalout was yesterday discharged as cared.

Public Health Department. Doctor H. Ross has been appointed sanitary inspector at a salary of £E. 50 per month. His pay will be charged to the credit opened for combating the plague. Dr. Ross will have his headquarters in Cairo.

Murderer Sentenced. The Native Court of Alexandria has sentenced Sai 1 Maragia, a Bedouin of Mariout, to imprisonment with hard labour for life, for murdering another Bedouin of that village on the 19th May last. The murderer, however, is still at large.

Ashrafl Syndicate, Ltd. This syndicate was registered on 23rd Jane with a capital of £10,003, in £1 share. Objects : To acquire, deal with, and turn to account any petroleum or oil-bearing lands in Egypt or elsewhere, and to adopt an agreement with W. Barrier. No initial public issue.

Hashish Smuggling. The coast guards have confiscated 1,400 kilos of hashish on the Red Sea coast. The Ministry of the Interior has received information to the effect that the coast guards have confiscated 14 camels laden with 1,042 kilos of hashish at Ghahat El Youha, near Suez.

Cotton In Palestine. The British vice-consul at Jaffa laments that all the efforts made by a Liverpool firm to promote the cultivation of cotton in Palestine have been fruitless, even though labour costs bat a shilling per day and land is one tenth the price of Egyptian land. The chief cause of the failure is said by the consul to be the incapacity and laziness of the natives.

Destitute Pilgrims On the order of the Turkish Governor of Jeddah 4V 2 destitute Moorish pilgrims who were at that town, left by a sailing craft for Suakin and have arrived there in a pitiable condition. The quarantine agent at Suakin telegraphed the news to the Quarantine Board at Alexandria, which has ordered the pilgrims to be placed under observation for ten days and requested the Egyptian Government to provide them with victuals and with the means for their return home.

Cattle Plague. Daring the week ended July 8, fifteen cases of cattle plague were notified in Egypt, nine of which occurred is the province of Minieh and six in Ghirgeh. According to the weekly official bulletin whioh is published by the Public Health Department, one of these cases occurred at Rayayna and two at Sawalem, both if the Tahta district, and one in the town of Tahta, of Ghirgeh province. In Minieh five oases were notified at Fait and four at Eoleab, both in the Pashn district.

Automobiles In the Desert The United States Consul-General, Mr. L. M. Iddings, reporting from Cairo, says that the prospect of the use of automobiles are better. Motors can at present be used only in and about Alexandria and Cairo, but the desert offers almost natural roads, and it is estimated that it will cost only from five to ten dollars per mile to make them perfect. The experiment has succeeded so far, and police inspection formerly made on camels, and taking six weeks for each trip, can new he made in two weeks.

An Arabic Poet M. Nacime El Azard, who composed some Arabic verses commemorating the marriage of King Alfonso XlII. and Queen Victoria of Spain and their preservation from death, has received the following letter from the King’s private secretary: Momiear.— J’ai l’honneur de vons informer en reponse k votre lettre da 15 Juin que Lears Majesty le Roi et la Reine out daigne me charger de vous exprimer la vive reconnaissance pour le pofeme qae vous avez compost eu arabe k l’occasion de leur manage, et de leur heureuse d6 ivrance da criminal attentat da 31 Mai. Lears Majesty ont la votre composition (trsdaction anglaipe) aveo grand plaisir. Recevez Monsieur l’assaranoe de ma consideration.—Le Comte de Andeno.

New Employment Registry. The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members repairing clerical or other assistance. Applications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts on Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: THE SITUATION IN EGYPT.
SIRE.GREY’S IMPORTANT STATEMENT
FULL TEXT OF SPEECH. (From our Corresponded.)
div.p: House of Commons, London, July 6. By old Parliamentary bands yesterday will be remembered as an important day—in fact, one of the most important since the present Government came into office. It is quite possible, however, that those who have only recently joined the ranks at Westminster did not attach a great deal of importance to the calm, temperate, and telling appeal made by Sir Edward Grey, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, but, judging by the articles which have appeared this morning in the daily papers all of which are unanimous in their approval of Sir Edward Grey’s firm attitude in very trying circumstances, it must now be patent to all the world that the present Government have every intention of supporting the authorities in Egypt in their conduct of the unfortunate out break at Denishwai.

In the earlier part of the evening the Foreign Minister was by himself on the Treasury Bench, evidently auspicious of the tactics of the Irish irreconcilables and their friends, who were desirous of embarrassing the Government over this episode. Lord Cromer had been for sometime an onlooker from the Peers’ Gallery. Sir Edward Grey, seeing that the right moment had arrived, commenced his statement. The word went round the precincts of the House that the Foreign Minister was “talking,” when there was at once a general entrance of members to hear what he had to say. He spoke with intense gravity, earnestness, and slowness, and said :—

I rise now, not because I wish to reply on the Congo debate at present, bat in order to make a short statement and an appeal to the House on a subject which has been touched on by Sir C. Dilke, and which is, if the House will only realise it, the most serious subject yet touched upon this evening—I mean the question of the present position in Egypt. Sir . Dilke spoke of the immense harm done by the first impression given by the report of the way in which those sentences on Egyptian natives were carried oat. I understood the House, when the sentences were first announced, to accept my statement that the tribunal had been the highest possible, and its character Bach as to guarantee that the trial had been fair. But that was followed by an account in the Press of the way in which the sentences were carried out. I am perfectly well aware of the painful impression produced by that account. U gave rise to two impressions, perhaps to three. Oon impression was that in executing the sentences the men who were to be hanged were compelled to look on while the protracted, so that it lasted for a period of | three hours. I am told the third impression was that the population had been compelled to attend and witness the executions. When I read that account in the Press, I made up my mind at once that, with a short account like that, the only fair and sensible thing to do was to say and think nothing until a fall report of the whole circumstances had been ed the sentences being carried out on the others. They were kept apart, in separate tents, and special pains were taken to prevent this. In the next place, the sentences were carried on circumstances of the case. The executions did not hour. In the third place, no one not on duty was compelled in the newspapers. (Cheers.) I wonld ask the Home to believe that when the Court which pronounced these sentences directed that they were to be carried out on the scene of the outrage, there fell to those on whom the duty rested of carrying oat the decree of the Court a serious and most painful duty, which had to be performed under considerable difficulties, and I ask the House to believe, as I believe, from information I have received, that it was carried out hi a way which did not lay anyone concerned open to the charge of being callous or even thoughtless. (Cheers). I have promised fall papers. Short telegraphic reports are all I have received so far, and I would ask the House to remember that in a matter of this importance to embark on a discussion before you have a fall report of the circumstances is certain to lead to things being said which when you get the full facts you will realise have not been fair to those concerned. (Hear, hear.) Already some unfairness has been done by the way in which Captain Macheh’s name has been brought into the matter, which I have done my best to repair in the reply I made to a question this afternoon as to Captain Maohell’s known character. But sorely it has been recognised for some time that of ail the English officials who are employed in the service of the Empire there are none of higher standing than those in Egypt, because of the great capacity shown by Lord Cromer and his great care in selecting men of ability, character, and fairness (Cheers.) Therefore, on the ground of mere fairness, I would ask the House not to embark on a debate

div.head: continued
div.p: of this subject until they have more papers. (Hear, hear.) Bat that is not the more serious ground, All this year fanatical feeling in Egypt has been on the increase. It has not been confined to Egypt, bat has spread along the north of Africa. It was for that reason that a little time ago the garrison had to be increased. The attack on the British officers recently is something which would never have occurred only a little time ago, and would not have occurred now bat for the fanatical feeling which has spread in Egypt during this year. Since that attack took place, and even before the trial of those condemned, one or two disagreeable and significant attacks bad been made upon, I think, British subjects, or, at any rate, Europeans, by natives. We may be on the eve of further measures necessary to protect Europeans in Egypt, and for the House of Commons to question the decision of a tribunal composed of the highest English and Egyptian judge is Egypt, is bound to have the effect of weakening the authority of the Egyptian Government. (Cheers.) As things are now, I say deliberately and with a fall sense of responsibility, that if the House of Commons does anything at this moment to weaken or destroy the authority of the Government as it exists in Egypt you will be face to face with a very serious situation, because if the fanatical feeling in Egypt gets the better of the constituted authority of the Egyptian Government yon are then face to face with the necessity for extreme measures. The work done by Lord Cromer has been widely recognised. If you compare Egypt to-day with the Egypt of twenty-five years ago, I doubt whether in any generation yon will find the lot of the common people improved so much as that of the Egyptian people. (Cheers). 1 know very well that the House is not going to allow the work to be swept away by a rush of fanatical passion. (Cheers.) I have promised fall papers, not because I doubt the fairness of the trial, but because when a wrong impression has once got afoot the only chance of removing it is to publish the fullest possible information. I know the House is determined not to allow the work done in Egypt to be undone, bat if we say anything in debate now to weaken the authority of the Egyptian Government, they may find themselves at any moment forced to take other measures—unconstitutional measures, which we are bound to take in an emergency, bat which no one would regret more than the present Government and the present House of Commons, though they might be compelled to do so. (Cheers.)

At the end of his statement cheers of approval rose from all parts of the House, save from the few irreconcilable?. The impression created by his remarks was excellent, and when members left at the close of the debate they went away feeling that' the Government was behind the authorities in Egypt, and determined to support them in their intention to suppress any lawless outbreaks in Egypt.

Earl Percy expressed satisfaction at the full statement which the Foreign Secretary had made and thought the House might have every confidence in leaving the matter to the judgement and discretion of Lord Cromer.
Despite Sir E. Grey's appeal, Mr. Dillon indulged in a violent attack upon the existing regime in Egypt

div.head: AFTER DENISHWAI.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has charged Kaimakam Melville Bey, one of its inspectors, to represent it at the council of discipline which met yesterday morning at the gouvernorat for the first time to try the officer who commanded the mounted police detatchment which was charged with the maitenance of order at Denishwai when the sentences were carried out.
The court was composed of the Governor of Alexandria, Major Hopkinson, and Melville Bey. At the time of going to press the decision of the Court had not been made known.

div.head: THE FRONTIER COMMISSION.
div.p: “A1 Mokattam” learns from El Arish that the the Commission for the delimitation of the Sinaitic frontier will leave Ratah on a steamer in about five days, unless some unexpected obstacle arises
The surveyors accompanying the commission, our contemporary adds, are hard at work on the maps of the delimitation which are to be submitted to the Ottoman members for their ratification.
Owen Bey, Director of Military Intelligence, arrived at El Arish and left for Rafah on the 5th instant.
In the House of Commons last week, Mr. Ashley enquired as to what progress had been made by the Joint Commission in the delimitation of the Turco-Egyptian frontier.

Sir E. Grey. — We understand that satisfactory progress is being made on the spot with the delimitation of the Turco-Egyptian frontier, and it is hoped that the map of the frontier will be finished soon.

div.head: FANATICISM IN EGYPT. IS IT EXISTENT ? AN ARTICLE BY MUSTAPHA KAMEL-
div.p: Paris July 11
The “Figaro” publishes a long article by Mustapha Pasha Kamel attacking the methods of the English and asserting that Mussulman fanaticism does not exist in Egypt. (Havas)

A correspondent writes :—I am interested, and indeed amused, by the attempts of the Nationalist Press to disprove all the accusations of fanaticism that have recently been levelled at the Egyptian Moslems. Personally, while not much alarmed by the violent language used by “Al Omma” during the Turkish crisis, or by the exaggerated dread of a Pan-Islamic outbreak, I have kept my eyes and ears open daring the last few months with results that I can only qualify as surprising. The amount of anti-European talk that has been going on in cafes, in the streets, in the Arab dancing halls, wherever, in fact, large numbers of town Moslems congregate, would drive into hysterical terror those good people who forget that the unkind proverb “El Masri yekhaf wa ma yikhtishish,” first uttered by some Cairene Solomon, is in many cases almost literally true.

Now the fact that Moslem history is a history of war between Moslem and non- Moslem, and that the teaching of the Koran is essentially military, must be taken into account in considering the present state of affairs. The majority of lower-class Moslems is totally uneducated, except for a more or less imperfect knowledge of the Koran. Non- Moslems, therefore, who are resident in Moslem countries are always inclined, and with reason, to suspect that a feeling of resentment against any European or Lon-Moslem nation may develop into what Sir Edward Grey describes as a wave of fanaticism, directed not against one non-Moslem community but against all.

The majority of educated Moslems in India, Turkey, and Egypt are of course averse to religions war. The Indian doctors of religion, in answer to appeals made to them in 1870-71 as to what were the necessary conditions of a religions war, replied that the whole matter hinged upon the question whether India was Dar ul Harb (the land of war) or Darb ul Islam. The great majority of doctors decided that the absence of protection and liberty to Mussulmans is essential in a Jehad, and that the Mussulmans of India, being protected by the State and having fall liberty to practise their religion and to make converts, dwelt in Dar ul Islam, or at least in Dar nl Amam (the land of peace). If these conditions applied to India in 1870 71, how much more do they apply to Egypt in 1906 ?

Is it too much, then, to ask the Ulema and religious leaders of Egypt to give their opinion on this matter? By so doing they would cut the ground from under the feet of few malcontents and intriguers who are trying to excite the ignorant against the British Occupation, which, I may say, has followed the British policy of tolerance towards the members of a somewhat intolerant creed. In Egypt there has of coarse been no interference whatever with the predominant creed, and in the Sudan the missionary is forbidden in large areas inhabited by Moslem Arabs and negroes.

Islam has moved with the times. The opinions formerly held by members of “heretical” sects, Druses. Babis, etc., are making way among educated Mohamedans in Egypt and to a greater extent in Turkey. I need only instance the movement on behalf of female education and the gradual disappearance of polygamy. Jehad was in former days aggressive—it is now, in theory at least, & defensive measure only to be used as a last resort, against an oppressive non Moslem Government. It is therefore to be hoped that with the advance of education in Egypt the anti-Christian feeling which still shows itself—e. g. in the reference to a dead “infidel” as. “the damned”—will disappear. Meantime nothing is to be gained by ignoring its existence on the one band or by displaying an exaggerated apprehension on the other. In my opinion the present unrest will subside without farther incident, to the great satisfaction of the vast majority of law-abiding Moslems and non-Moslems who compose the Egyptian people.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DIJLTA LAND AND INVESTMENT CO.
div.p: Owing to the fact that a misunderstanding has arisen as to the meaning of Art. 10 of the resolutions to be passed at an extraordinary general meeting of the above company, to be held in London on the 19th July 1906,namely “That the capital of the company be increased from £250,0C0 to £500,000,” we have been requested by the manager of the company to inform the public that the object of the directors in seeking to acquire this power, is not with the intention of making any immediate issue of capital, bot to enable them in the future, should advantageous business offer, to take up the same. Whenever any such occasion arises, and fresh capital has to be Called up, ample notice will be given to shareholders of any such issue, which will be offered pro rata to existing shareholders at that time.

div.head: ATTACK ON ENGLISHMAN- TRIAL AT CHIBIN-EL KOM. A LENIENT SENTENCE.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.) Chibin-el-Kom, Tuesday. To-day, before Hassan Bey Nabih, at the Parquet, Mohamed Masr was accused of committing an assault on Mr. Ashton, Inspector of Irrigation, at Esbet Omar Hashala on the 14th June. The case for the prosecution was conducted by the Parquet.

Mr. Ashton’s evidence showed that on Jane 14, the day after the Denishwai ontrage. while inspecting Quesna Canal accompanied by the sheikh el-esbet, he approached three men to arrest them for working their sakiehs out of rotation. The three men defied the inspector, threatening that if he approached they would drown him in the canal.

Taking no notice of the threats, Mr. Ashton and the sheikh el-esbet advanced, when Mob. Masr threw a brick which struck Mr. Ashton’s horse. Mr. Ashton dismounted and approached the men. Masr then threw another brick, which truck Mr. Ashton on the month, breaking one tooth and loosening others.

The sheikh el-esbet refused to assist Mr. Ashton, and refused to give the name of the assailant, or his own name, or the name of the esbet, so Mr. Ashton mounted his horse and galloped to the next village, where he reported the case.
In his evidence given at the preliminary enquiry the sheik-el-esbet said he was present and saw the assault, but to-day, at the trial, he denied seeing anything at all of the assault.
Two other native witnesses at the preliminary enquiry said they saw the brick being thrown by Moh. Masr, but at the trial to-day totally denied this.
After hearing the counsel for the defence, Hassan Bey Nabih sentenced the prisoner four months’ hard labour.
Chibin-el-Kom, Thursday. I understand that the Parquet is dissatisfied with the verdict in the Ashton case, and appealing against the sentence.

div.head: THEATRE ABBAS, CAIRO. THE GEISHA.
div.p: Cairo has eagerly awaited the advent of Lombardo’s theatrical company in the hopes that one might at last discover a really enjoyable means of passing these stifling summer evenings in genuine enjoyment. To judge from the doubt of this company at the Theatre Abbas on Tuesday evening, oar hopes are at last realised. To all theatre-going Britishers The Geisha is well known, and is usually very well received when represented by a good company. The English musical comedy of latter days has, unfortunately, most sadly, bat there are a few productions of the last ten years to which one can listen with pleasure and among these The Geisha may be reckoned. Today’s musical comedy has become hut a succession of variety “tarns,1 almost entirely unconnected by any plot, whereas the music to which the various items are set is often only worthy of a barrel-organ. The Geisha, however, can boast of a discernible plot, which, moreover, is well carried out, and its music, though not of the highest order, is, nevertheless, pleasing.

Though several faults might be found with the representation of the Italian company now performing in Cairo, it was on the whole excellent. Having spoken of faults, let ns first of all mention them, but at the same time, we must say that they were insufficient to spoil the general effect, to which little exception could be taken, the orchestra was fairly well-balanced, though perhaps the bass instruments were every now and then somewhat too prominent, bat they were as a rule rather slow in “attack” and generally dragged slightly. As Mimosa San Signorina Baldi failed to impart the necessary “verve.” Except for a somewhat exaggerated tremelo, which was noticeable in nearly all the principals, she sang excellently and, indeed, she has an exceptionally clear and pleasing voice, but she made a not inconsiderable mistake in giving so slow a rendering to all her songs. The ohoras left much to be desired in their singing, the sopranos being often distinctly harsh and almost discordant at times, while the tenors were very feeble. Finally, and perhaps mainly, the representation was too much of a parody of this popular English musical comedy and not a sufficiently literal translation.

These were the principal faults which could be found and now we mast mete out the considerable praise which is due to the company. With the exception of the insufficiently representative costumes, no fault could be found with the staging. The scenery was excellent, the manner in which the chorus per formed was faultless, and the changing coloured lights gave a splendid effect to the dancing. The principal parts were very well rendered, especially those of Mimosa San by Signorina Baldi, Dick Cunninham by Signor E. Saoohi, and Wun Hi by Signor E Urbano. As Lady Constance, Signor G. Parole was rather too farcical. The only fault which could be found with Signora C. Leoni as Molly Seamore was the occasional harshness of her low notes; otherwise she sang well and acted her part admirably. As we said before, several faults could be found with the details of the performance, but the stage management minimised these and the general effect was most successful. 8hould the company continue as they have begun we can readily assert their exceptional qualifications for giving ns an acceptable evening’s amusement—that is, for Cairo!

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, will leave tor Europe at the end of the month.

It is rumoured that Mohamed Shukri Pasha, Mondir of Menoufieh, now wishes to give up his post and return to the Judicial Department. Shukri Pasha is applying for the poet left vacant by the death of the late A’i Bey Fakhri, in the Mixed Tribunals.

Major Pine-Coffin has addressed a letter to the general officer commanding the Army of Occupation wherein he expresses thanks to the doctors of the Public Health Department who treated him while in Tantah hospital. The letter has been forwarded to the Department, which has transmitted it to the doctors named.
Moussa Bey Ismet has been appointed acting Governor of Ismailia daring the absence of the Governor.

The marriage of Mr. Ernest Richmond, inspector to the Ministry of Public Works, to Margaret Muriel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lubbock, will take place at St. Peter’s Church, Eaton-square, London, on the 17th inst. A reception will afterwards be held at 82, Eaton square.

At St. George’s, Hanover-square, last Thursday, Major Audley R. Lempriere, Lancashire Fasiliers, attached to the Egyptian Army, son of the late Captain G.R. Lempriere, R.E., was married to Mrs. Amelia Ruth Trafford, widow of the late Major Lionel Trafford, of The Hill Court, Ross, Hereford. The Rev. Clifford Rickards performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. David Anderson, Vicar of St. George’s. The bride, who was given away by her brother-in-law, General Sir Edward Hopton, K.C.B., wore a dress of cream crepe de chine, trimmed with antique duchesse lace. She was atttended by Miss B. Stevenson, who wore a pretty dress of cornflower blue 4olienne trimmed with Irish lace. Major H.A. Lempriere, D.S.O., 7th Dragoon Gaards, brother of the bridegroom, acted as best man. The honeymoon is being spent in Scotland.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy, Port Said, we notice the Hon. Capt. Forbes, Capt. Evans, Capt. Rome, Capt Belhell, El Kaim. Anderson Bey, Major and Mrs. Cave, Lieut. Wilson and family, Mr. I. Fondor, Mr. A. C. Peaoh, Mrs. Berry and daughter, Mr. Norman Wilkinson, Judge Holmes and family, Capt. S. S. Flower, Mr. H. K. Baynes, Mr. Peny, Miss Wilson, Mr. C. Bnkett, Mr. and Mme Weiss, Mr. Babb, Mr. and Mrs. Robb, Judge and Mrs. Perry, Mr. Ed. Tilche, Baron E. de Menasce, Dr. S. Voronoff, Omar Bey Saltan, Mr. Adams, Mr. S. Soronos, Mr. A. Monferrato.

div.head: GREAT EXHIBITION FOR CAIRO.
div.p: A correspondent sends ns an interesting suggestion which at least deserves consideration. He says:—

Most of the countries claiming attention in the world have followed the lead given to England by the inauguration of the first Great Exhibition by the Prince Consort, now so long ago that few of ns care to remember the date.

Since then we have seen show after show, world’s fairs, and mammoth exhibitions. At first given with the idea of Blowing the industries of a nation, this element has gradually in many snob exhibitions been overshadowed by the attempts to entertain visitors by sights representative of nation! life and character In this respect many Anglo-Egyptians are familiar with the caricatures of Assouan villages and other sights supposed to be familiar in Egypt. Occasionally, however, as in “Venice in London” and later in “Austria in London,” Imre Kiralfry, the great entrepreneur of exhibitions, has really given a first- class show. Bat these are at the best merely to interest and entertain and have as their chief object the paying of a dividend. The industrial exhibitions have generally, unless subsidised and managed by a State Government, also been financially a success.

Would it not be possible, say in the season at Cairo in 1908 or even 1909, to have a Great Exhibition representative of all that Egypt can show from her ancient past to her picturesque present! Of course, Cairo is an exhibition in itself. Bat would it not be possible in one space almost under the shadow of the Pyramids to collect interesting exhibits from all parts of the world of all that is modern in industrial development side by side with the antiquities of Egypt, post and present?

The exhibition of horsemanship, to say nothing of camel racing by the Bedonins, before the Prince of Wales, was only one of many instances which could be cited to show that Egypt could provide special pageants and sports of worldwide interest. As we are always having dinned into oar ears, East meets West at Port Said, or ought to, but does it; perhaps the attractions of Cairo, backed op by judicious worldwide advertising, the enterprise of our tourist and hotel companies, and possibly the sympathy of the Government might all combine in making succesful a great Oriental or other exhibition in Cairo.

Come along yon Barnnms, Kiralfies, Liptons or anyone gifted with organizing powers and better persuasive force against apathy, work op this idea or at best marshal all the objections to it that ingenuity can devise.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET Kearsley and Cunningham's Weekly Report
div.p: Liverpool, July 5. Egyptian Cotton is still neglected, the aotoa1 sales being very small. Quotations are reduced 1/9d per lb, except tor Fine Brown, which is lower. For Futures a moderate business has been done and the latest values are delivery: — July 9.51d Oct. 9.9 Jan. 8.16 Aug. 9.88 Nov. 8.36 Sept. 9.27 Dec. 8.25

American Futures. The Market this week has again been dull and inanimate, and the business has been of the most restricted character. In anticipation of the Bureau report prices declined 5 @ 6 points, bat later, most of the decline has been recovered, to-day’s closing values being 2 @ 3 points lower for July, July/August, and August/September deliveries, and 1 point decline to unchanged for the other positions, from those of last Thursday. The Bureau report, estimating the condition at 83.3 against 84.6 last month, was not quite up to expectation, bat as the weather since the 25th Jane, the date at which it i3 compiled, has been very favourable, it has had very little influence. The whole interest in the situation for the present is concentrated a poo the weather map, and this is fully demonstrated by the absence of all speculation, and the hand to month takings of spinners. Everyone is waiting upon the weather reports:—

div.head: THE Egyptian Delta Land & Investment Company, Limited,
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the above Company will be held at Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street, in the City of London on Thursday, the 19th day of July 1906 at 2 o’clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Relations, or Resolutions to a similar effect. If Resolutions 1 to 9 inclusive should be passed by the requisite majority, they will be submitted for confirmamation to a subsequent General Meeting to be hereafter convened so as to become Special Resolutions.

div.head: RESOLUTIONS
div.p: That the Memorandum and Articles Association be varied as follows :—

By striking out from Section 3, subsection (a) of the Memorandum of Association the words “in any district” and by sub stituting for the words “in which the Railways belonging to or that may at any time hereafter belong to the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, or any extension or branch thereof existing or hereafter constructed or proposed to be constructed, may serve or be intended to serve” occurring in the same subsection the words “or in the Sudan.”
That Article 75 of the Articles of Association of the Company be altered by striking out the words commencing “and every exercise of the power” down to the end of that Article.
That Article 81 be altered by striking out the words “or a person to be nominated as hereinafter provided by the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited.”

1. That Article 85 be altered by striking ont the words “provided that this prohibition shall not apply to any Contract dealing or transaction with the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited.” 2. That Article 86 be altered by striking out all words after the words “shall be vacant.” 3. That Article 87 be altered by striking oat the words “save as aforesaid” appearing in the first line of sneb Article, 4. That Article 89 be struck oat and that there be substituted therefor the following Article “The remuneration of the Directors “shall be the sum of £250 per annum to “each of the Directors and £500 per “annum to the Chairman, and such “remuneration shall be deemed to accrae “de die in diem. The remuneration shall “be exclusive of the sums, if any, which “under the provisions of these Presents “the Board may agree to pay to any "Director on account of special services.” 8 That Article 90 be altered by striking out the words “provided be be approved by the Board of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited.” 9 That Article 96 be altered by striking out the words “one Director” and sabstituting therefor the words “two Direc tors.” 10 That the Capital of the Company be increased from £250,000 to £500,000. 11 That the Memoradam of Agreement between the Company and the Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, now submitted to the Meeting and initialled by the Chairman for the purpose? of identification be approved and authorised to be entered into (subject to such alterations as the Board may think fit), and that the Board be authorised to enter into such further or other agreements a3 they may consider desirable for carrying such Memorandum of Agreement into effect.
By Order of the Board, F. J. HORNE, Secretary.

Dated 29th June, 1906. Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer are reminded that it they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company they must first deposit their Bearer Warrant, together with a statement in writing of their names and addressee either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, ie, not later than the 16th July, or with the National Bank of Egypt, Cairo, or Alexandria ten clear days before the date of the Meeting, i e.% not later than 7th July, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. div.head: TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS. ARMY REFORM. LORD MILNER AND CONSCRIPTION. DEBATE IN THE LORDS.
div.p: London, July 11. House of Lords.—Lord Milner expressed himself in favour of conscription, and said that a great nation should rely for defence on the whole manhood and not be limited to the professional class.

Lord Lanadowne declared that people were puzzled by the innumerable army reform schemes, which they have begun to regard in a despairing light Lord Ripon said that in view of Mr. Haldane’s forthcoming statement it was impossible to enter into the details of the Government’s schemes. He deprecated compulsion. ( Reuter)

div.head: AMERICA AND TURKEY. THE EMBASSY QUESTION
div.p: Washington, July 11. The Government has formally notified Turkey of their immediate intention of creating an Embassy in Constantinople, to which Turkey has objected and appealed to Washington unsuccessfully. She has now informed America that the creation of an Embassy requires an agreement between the two countries in question, which, in this case, does not exist, (R.)

div.head: ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATION RUSSIAN ADMIRAL.
div.p: Sebastopol, July 11 An attempt was made, to-day, to assassinate Admiral Chukhnic. He was wounded and has been removed to hospital. {Reuter) Sebastopol, July 11. Admiral Chokhnin has been wounded in an attempt on his life. f Havas)

div.head: FLEETS VISIT TO RUSSIA.
div.p: London, July 11. The Admiralty has announced that seven battleships and six cruisers will start for the Baltic on 21st inst. and will visit Libau, Hango, Kronstadt, Reval, Pillao, and Luebeck. {Reuter)

div.head: DEATH PENALTY IN RUSSIA.
div.p: St Petersburg, July 11. The Council of the Empire has remitted the law suppressing the death penalty to a Commission for consideration. (Havas)

div.head: FRENCH AMNESTY.
div.p: Paris, July 11. The Chamber of Deputies has passed the Amnesty Bill. (Havas)

div.head: HOME CRICKET
div.p: London, July 11. Hampshire beat Northamptonshire by wickets. {Reuter

div.head: UM RUS OPERATIONS.
div.p: The progress report for the half-month ended 16th June states : -“Main shaft sunk 14 ft. to total depth 661 ft. 450 ft level northeast was driven 27 ft. total length 333 ft. Sample at 338 ft. assayed a trace over 3 ins of quartz. 450 ft. level south-west extended 29 ft. total length 390 ft. From 365-375 ft. vein averaged 17 ins. wide, carrying a trace Of gold. At 375 ft. drive entered dyke No. 11. 450 ft. level south-west, Winza No. 1, was sunk 18 ft. total depth 24 ft. The quartz has averaged 11 ins wide, carrying 15 dwts. 23 grs. 350 ft. level south west extended to 594 ft. or 30 ft. driven for half-month. Holed into western shaft crosscut at 580 ft. A sample at 565 ft. assayed 5 dwts. 12 grs. over 24 ins. 350 ft. level soUth west, winze No. 3, sunk 22 ft, total depth 86 ft. The vein averaged 14 ins in width, assaying a trace only. div.head: THE POWERS AND ABYSSINIA. REPORTED AGREEMENT.
div.p: The terms of an understanding relative to Abyssinia were (the "Standard’s” Paris correspondent says) finally settled at last Wednesday’s meeting in London between Sir Edward Grey, M. Cambon (the Frenoh Ambassador), and Signor Tittoni, on behalf of Italy, subject, of course, to the approval of the French and Italian Governments. A farther meeting was held on Friday to approve the definite text of the agreement. The understanding follows the main lines given in "The Standardon June 2G last. First of all, the maintenance of the status quo in Abyssinia is guaranteed. The country has been put as far outside the pale of political intrigue as possible, and it will be difficult to make it the subject of an Algeciras Conference. At any rate, there will be little chance of three signatory Powers falling out. In order to define as Nearly as may be the status quo, the exact position of Abyssinia to-day with regard to neighbouring Powers is set out in the agreement by the inclusion in its schedule of all the agreements entered into by those Powers with the Government of the Negus. Questions of interpretation may arise, but the agreements themselves are ipso facto accepted as valid. Equality of commercial [ rights of all nations is, of course, recognised.

As to that part of the understanding which deals with the future (continues the correspondent) and which endeavours to anticipate the occurrence of possible untoward events, following the demise of a Sovereign or some other internal crisis, I am informed that it was found impossible to lay down more than the main lines of a common policy. The signatory Powers will consult before taking measures to protect foreign interests, or the lives and property of strangers placed in jeopardy, and any one of them will notify the others of her intention to take individual action, in the event of necessity for such a step arising. Finally, the railway difficulty has been settled. The Ethiopian Railway Company’s concession, from Jibutil to Addis-Abeba, is recognised. The company will remain French, but will be reorganised, and one British and one Italian director will be added to the board of direction. In this way it is considered that international interests will be protected, under the farther agreement not to allow a competing line to be constracted from the east coast. I say a competing line, because Italy is left free to build a railway linking her Erythrian colony with her Somaliland possessions, which may, if financial and engineering difficulties ever permit its construction, have more than one terminus on the east coast. The successful conclusion of this agreement shows how groundless were the assertions made a few days ago, in a section of the French Press, about the uncompromising attitude of Signor Tittoni. As was stated in ‘‘The Standard there never has been any justification for French criticism of Signor Tittoni’s actions, and real fear of the breakdown of the negotiations, now happily terminated.

div.head: THE ABYSSINIAN RAILWAY.
div.p: Mr. Ashley asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs last week whether, in any agreement arrived at between Great Britain and other Powers, with reference to the Abyssinian Railway, he proposed to ensure that there shall be equality of economic treatment for the goods of all nations carried by the railway, and that there shall be the same equal treatment at the port of Jibuti and on the frontier of Abyssinia.
Sir E. Grey. — His Majesty’s Government are fully alive to the importance of ensuring equality of treatment on the railway for the commerce of all nations.

div.head: BISHOP POTTER’S DISCLAIMER
div.p: With regard to the statement alleged to have been made recently by Bishop Potter, of New York, that “there is no love lost between England and America,” that distinguished American, in a letter to the "Daily Express,” denies the statement attributed to him.

div.head: ' MONEY AND SHARE MARKET (From our Financial Correspondent.)
div.p: London, July 6. The Money Market. The usual half-yearly movements of mon6y due to the window-dressing called for by bankers’ balance-sheets, as well as the dividend distribution, including about six millions in dividends on Consols, has to some extent obscured the monetary position daring the last few days, bat now the effect of these is clearing away, a very manifest easy tone is supervening. Nor does it appear likely that anything will interfere to prevent a continuance of easy money for several months to come. It is true the Bank shows considerable withdrawals, notably by the public, no doubt for holiday purposes, and that the reserve has been reduced in its proportion to liabilities to 41 1/4 %, bat gold shipments to America, which last week appeared to be imminent, have not taken place, and in view of the large useless balance held by the Treasury of the United States, it is not thought likely that any large amount will be exported without the Treasury coming to the rescue of the markets in some form, as it certainly would not pay the United States to create dearness of money in Europe, in view of the fact that they have borrowed largely, and will want to repay their loans. The floating supplies in Paris are being freely offered to bankers here, and in view of the steady flow of gold from the mines it would appear that there should be no scarcity, but rather a plethora, of money for some time. What will be the requirements of gold in America in the Autumn is the question bankers are asking themselves. It is known that the demand will be very large, bat before that time the Fowler Bill may have become law, or some other means found of making use of the Treasury snr pins, equivalent to £70,000,000 sterling, now lying idle. Silver is in good demand, and although India has a large stock, the good crops there will probably necessitate purchases almost equal to tho.se of last year.

The Stock Markets. Russia and South Africa continue to be the bete noire of the Stock Markets. This unhappy combination, which has given endless trouble daring the past 18 months, is becoming an increasingly disturbing element in the financial world, and there is promise of much more serious trouble before a settlement in either case is effected.

Russia appears to be rapidly approaching the general upheaval, which has been so long anticipated. As for South Africa, the condition of things there is unsatisfactory in the extreme. The chief industry of the country has been seriously crippled by the constant interference of the Government since they came into office, following upon the disturbance caused by the war, and the enormous depreciation in the value of the stocks of the mining concerns has had an incalculably depressing effect upon investment business generally. In view of the hostile attitude of his Majesty's Ministers from the first, it is doubtfal if the latest announcement of Mr. Churchill that importations of Chinese to the Rand are to cease in November will cause much alarm.

During the latter part of this week markets have shown a slightly improved tone, the revival, as was the case last week, commencing on Wednesday, when most sections showed welcome increases of business. Under this influence prices sharply advanced, and although there was not a great amount of activity yesterday, the tone remained firm. The rumour that the Russian Cabinet was about to resign, and that in the re-constitution several intelligential members of the Dama would be elected to office, served to bring Russians, to an extent, out of the Slongh of Despond into which they had fallen at the end of last week, and though there is no farther information to hand that confirms or denies the rumour, the bonds have not shown much relapse. Paris is now a better feature. The large banks have been lending their assistance, with the result that the large quantities of Russian and other stocks which have been floating about on the Bourse are being absorbed. The outlook generally is, therefore, brighter.
CONSOLS

The gilt-edged market has been unsteady, and although at one time Consols managed to go above 88, they fell back yesterday to 87J, They leave off lower to-night at 87^. It may he mentioned that the Consols carry-over on Monday showed a decline in the price during the account of 1, after deducting the dividend. The script of the new Irish Land Loan is now quoted discount.
Foreign Bonds.

In this section, Russians have not yet recovered from the heavy bear attack. The tone has been less pessimistic, but the price rather lower than our last quotation, though better than the closing figures last Saturday. The Fours finish at 76, and the new loan 41 discount, after being 5 % discount on Saturday. Japanese kept firm np to yesterday, when slight declines occurred in two or three of the series. The first Fives are J up oi the week at 101}, after being 102, but the Fours are 2} down at 90}.
Home Ralls.

The terrible railway accident at Salisbury . on Sunday seriously affected home railway stocks at the beginning of the week, the shares of the London and 8oath Western falling 2} j points. A batch of highly gratifying traffic returns to Complete the half year helped to r dispel the gloom, and the shares of the leading , companies, with the exception of the Metro-

div.p: politan District, which lost }, put on from | to full point. Yesterday again the tone was very firm, and farther advances were registered, North Westerns gaining 3/4. Today, however, there has been some slight liquidation, and prices close rather down.

The Midland Company head the list of traffics with a gain £28,000, due to the holding of the Royal Agricultural Society’s show at Derby, and the London and North Western have an increase of £20,000. The only decrease that of the North London, amounting to £363, which comes on top of a loss of £349 in the corresponding week last year.
Americans

After opening irregular owing to the look of support from Wall 8t. as the result of increased money calls, the American railway market considerably benefited by the more cheerful tone on Wednesday, and notwithstanding the fact that New York was dosed in celebration of Independence Day, with the consequent limitation of business, prices advanced appreciably, one or two of the shares, which had been very depressed earlier, showing highly satisfactory improvements. Thus, Chicago Milwaukee, which had lost 5 1/2, put on 2 points, and Wabash "B” Debentures, after being 5 down, gained 2} points. Yesterday the good tone was maintained, and several farther advances occurred, there being declines in only three oases at the close.
Egyptians

The Egyptian market ba9 been a little more active lately, but with the depression all round, especially in the Kaffir section, it is surprising that these stocks hold their price so well. National Bank of Egypt, after being 251/4 buyers, have reacted quickly to 25}, but Agricultural Banks maintain their quotation of 91/2—3/4. Daira Sanieh are flat without any support, the price of the Ordinary being 16}-} and the Deferred 95-99. Delta Preference are unchanged at about 113/4, but Delta Land and Investment, after being as low as 3}, are much better at 31/2 rather bid. Abyssinian Banks are only discount and not a very good market, even at this price. Union Fonciere are quoted 6-}. Land Banks are supposed to be 8}-J, and New Egyptian 1}-}. Daira Sngar remain firm at 5, and Corporation of Western Egypt are about} premium. Egyptian Markets are an mentioned at . bat Salt and Soda are better at 1 }. Egyptian Estates are If-}, and the Deferred are nominally 9-11. Bank of Romania at 10} are easier, without any business to report. Khedivial Mail Ord. are wanted at 32s. 6d.
Mining

In the South African market there has been farther heavy selling of Kaffirs, and though this ceased for a time yesterday, it was resumed after the statement made by the Undersecretary for the Colonies regarding Chinese Labour became known. Rand Mines and East Rands declined }, Modderfontein 5/16, and Goldfields }. In the Diamond section Premier Deferred, which had had a sharp rise on Wednesday, lost }.

The Egyptian mining market is lifeless, and most of the shares have not been mentioned. With the exception of United Africans, which are } lower, at }, there are no changes to report The closing prices to night are as follow :

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: Yesterday witnessed the prettiest racing that has been seen this season, 18 boats in all joining in the races. The much-abused handicap, which has been strenuously adhered to by the committee in spite of all complaints, worked out very well indeed, as will be seen by the above times, eight boats in CUbs I crossing the finishing line well within four minutes, and the whole of Class II. finishing also in approximately four minutes. The wind was moderate from the N.W. and there was a typical summer breeze, similar to those on which the handicaps have been based since last year, hence the success of the same.
